S2095-4956(22)00576-9 10.1016/j.jechem.2022.10.036 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Working principle of furfural-fueled liquid flow fuel cell system developed in this work for production of furoic acid, hydrogen gas, hydrogen peroxide with electricity generation. (a) Structure of the liquid flow fuel cell system. (b) Electricity generation with HNO3 activated VO2 +/VO2+ as the cathode electron carriers for four-electron reduction of oxygen. (c) Electricity generation with sodium anthraquinone-2-sulfonate as a cathode electron carrier for two-electron reduction of oxygen to produce H2O2 in catholyte. Fig. 2 (a) Comparison on the power density of the LFFCs with different modified Ni foam cathodes at room temperature. (b) SEM of Ag2O nano-particles. (c) SEM images of Ag2O modified Ni foam anode. (d) EDS images of Ag2O modified Ni foam anode. Fig. 3 Batch and fed-batch operation for furoic acid and H2 production with electricity generation using the LFFC system with (VO2)2SO4 as the cathode electron carrier. (a) Output current density and quantity of transferred electrons during a batch discharging process. (b) Change of furfural and furoic acid concentrations in anolyte in a batch discharging process. (c) Furoic acid yield and the total Faraday efficiency in a batch discharging process. (d) Output current density and transferred electric quantity during a continuous fed-batch discharging process. (e) Change of furfural and furoic acid concentrations in anolyte in a continuous fed-batch discharging process. (f) Furoic acid yield and the total Faraday efficiency in a continuous fed-batch discharging process at room temperature. All the discharging were operated at constant output voltage of 0.6 V. Fig. 4 Furoic acid and H2O2 production in batch and fed-batch operation. (a) Current density and quantity of transferred in batch process. (b) Change of furfural, furoic acid and H2O2 concentrations in batch process. (c) Faraday efficiency and furoic acid yield in batch process. (d) Current density and quantity of transferred electrons in fed-batch process. The green arrows indicate that 100 mM furfural was fed at this time point. (e) Change of furfural, furoic acid and H2O2 concentrations in fed-batch process. (f) Faraday efficiency and furoic acid yield in fed-batch process. All the discharging were performed under short-circuit condition in order to achieve quick transfer of electrons to cathode for H2O2 production. Graphical abstract A novel liquid flow fuel cell (LFFC) reaction system was developed to achieve electricity generation and furfural oxidation for furoic acid production with release of H2 on Ag2O@Ni foam anode and production of H2O2 in catholyte under mild conditions with air as the final oxidant by newly proposed reaction mechanisms. Conventional chemical oxidation of aldehydes such as furfural to corresponding acids by molecular oxygen usually needs high pressure to increase the solubility of oxygen in aqueous phase, while electrochemical oxidation needs input of external electric energy. Herein, we developed a liquid flow fuel cell (LFFC) system to achieve oxidation of furfural in anode for furoic acid production with co-production of hydrogen gas. By controlling the electron transfer in cathode for reduction of oxygen, efficient generation of electricity or production of H2O2 were achieved. Metal oxides especially Ag2O have been screened as the efficient catalyst to promote the oxidation of aldehydes, while liquid redox couples were used for promoting the kinetics of oxygen reduction. A novel alkaline-acidic asymmetric design was also used for anolyte and catholyte, respectively, to promote the efficiency of electron transfer. Such an LFFC system achieves efficient conversion of chemical energy of aldehyde oxidation to electric energy and makes full use the transferred electrons for high-value added products without input of external energy. With (VO2)2SO4 as the electron carrier in catholyte for four-electron reduction of oxygen, the peak output power density (P max) at room temperature reached 261 mW/cm2 with furoic acid and H2 yields of 90% and 0.10 mol/mol furfural, respectively. With anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS) as the cathodic electron carrier, P max of 60 mW/cm2 and furoic acid, H2 and H2O2 yields of 0.88, 0.15 and 0.41 mol/mol furfural were achieved, respectively. A new reaction mechanism on furfural oxidation on Ag2O anode was proposed, referring to one-electron and two-electron reaction pathways depending on the fate of adsorbed hydrogen atom transferred from furfural aldehyde group. Keywords Oxidation of furfural Liquid flow fuel cell Electricity generation Hydrogen production Electron transfer 1 Introduction Production of biomass-based chemicals has been considered as one of the most important way to reduce the dependence on fossil resources and decrease the net emission of CO2 [1]. Various value-added chemicals can be produced from biomass as important platform chemicals for further production of different fuels and materials [2]. Among the various bio-based chemicals, furoic acid (FCA) that can be produced by oxidation of furfural is a versatile chemical for the production of a variety of pharmaceutical drugs, fragrances, biofuels etc. [3]. Currently, industrial production of FCA is primarily achieved by the Cannizaro disproportionation reaction in aqueous NaOH solution, which results in formation of furfuryl alcohol and sodium furoate [4]. However, this process suffers from the drawbacks of low yield of FCA and difficulties in the separation of the products. Many strong oxidants have been used for oxidation of furfural to form FCA, including H2O2 [5], quinolinium dichromate [6], TEMPO, organic peracids [7]. Nevertheless, many by-products may be formed during oxidation due to the strong oxidizing ability of these oxidants, leading to decrease in the FCA selectivity. Therefore, selective oxidation of furfural to FCA with cheaper and less polluting oxidants such as O2 is necessary for green processing and improving FCA yield. Various metal catalysts supported on different metal oxides have been developed to catalyze the oxidation of furfural by oxygen with FCA yield of 80%–99% depending on the catalysts and reaction medium used. Ren et al. reported that Pt atomic clusters catalysts can obtain 99% furfural conversion with 97% FCA yield [8]. However, the reusability of the metal-based heterogeneous catalysts still needs further improvement in their stability. For example, FCA yield decreased from 92% to 65% when Ag2O/CuO catalyst was reused for 18 batches [9]. Moreover, when these catalysts are directly used for furfural oxidation by air or oxygen gas in a solid–liquid-gas tri-phase system, the kinetics of the reactions may be limited by poor solubility of oxygen in the aqueous phase. To increase the surface area, the catalysts are usually prepared with small size, for example, to form nanoparticles. The catalytic efficiency could be improved, but separation of the product with the catalysts might be problematic. Furthermore, such a tri-phase is relatively difficult to achieve continuous operation, leading to limited potential for scale-up application. Electrochemical oxidation of furfural to FCA is a promising approach with good possibility for continuous operation. Various anode catalysts have been used for promoting the efficiency, including metal oxides such as PbO2, MnO2 [10], and noble metal such as Pt [11], Au [12] and Ru [13]. High efficiency can be obtained by electrochemical oxidation and the process can be easily controlled by adjusting the voltage applied on the electrolytic cell, but the process still needs input of external energy, electricity. Thermodynamically, oxidation of furfural by molecular oxygen can take place easily, because O2 has much high redox potential than aldehyde group. However, kinetically, the reaction proceeds very slowly, and therefore, catalysts are needed to promote reaction rates. The essential of chemical oxidation reaction is electron transfer from the reductants to the oxidants. Therefore, this work is aimed to develop a novel reaction system to achieve efficient oxidation of furfural under mild condition with liquid flow fuel cell (LFFC) technology. Namely, by using the principle of Galvanic battery, we have proposed a coupled system to achieve FCA production and co-generation of electricity with furfural as a “fuel” and oxygen as the final electron acceptor. This system converts the chemical energy of furfural oxydation to electricity, and make full use of the electrons released thus achieving multi-products co-production. For example, by coupling two-electron reduction of O2 in the cathode, hydrogen peroxide (HP) can be produced. The kinetics of electron transfer in this system also could be easily controlled by screening anode and cathode catalysts as well as the external resistance loading, thus easily adjusting the product profile. We also found that hydrogen gas could be produced via transfer of the hydrogen atom of the aldehyde group on certain anode catalyst, which resulted in a new proposed reaction mechanism on Ag2O anode. This work thus may provide novel ideas for coupling oxidation of aldehydes for production of corresponding products with generation of electricity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals The main chemicals used in the experiments, including nickel foam, furfural, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), furoic acid, silver nitrate (AgNO3), potassium hydroxide (KOH), sulfuric acid (H2SO4), ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3), vanadium pentoxide (V2O5), carbon black (carbon ECP), poly(1,1-difluoroethylene) (PVDF), Pd/carbon black, Pt/Carbon black and sodium anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS) were purchased form the local suppliers and used as received. Two proton exchange membranes, namely Nafion 115 and Nafion 117 manufactured by DuPont Company (USA) were used in the liquid flow fuel cell for electricity generation and hydrogen peroxide production. 2.2 Preparation of Ag2O@Ni foam electrode Ag2O powder was prepared using the co-precipitation method. Specifically, 10 mL 0.2 mol/L AgNO3 solution was added into 10 mL 1 M KOH solution drop by drop under stirring. The mixed solution was agitated for 24 h under stirring and then centrifuged to precipitate Ag2O particles. The obtained Ag2O precipitates were washed and freeze-dried for several times prior to use. The Ag2O@Ni foam electrode was prepared by mixing Ag2O powders and carbon ECP conductive agents, and PVDF binder with a weight ratio of 10:1:1. Typically, 200 mg Ag2O powder, 20 mg carbon EPC, and 20 mg PVDF were placed in a clean agate mortar. After thoroughly grinding, 1.4 mL NMP was added into the mixture to form slurry. Then the prepared slurry was equably pasted on a 10 mm long × 10 mm wide × 2 mm thick Ni foam and then dried in a 60 °C oven for 12 h. The geometric area of the electrode was about 1 cm2 and the loading amount of Ag2O was 33 mg per electrode. The preparation of Pt/C@Ni foam and Pd/C@Ni foam electrodes was similar to that of Ag2O@Ni foam electrode. 2.3 Assembly of the liquid flow fuel cell The liquid flow fuel cell (LFFC) was manufactured by Wuhan Zhisheng New Energy Co., Ltd., which was consisted of two graphite bipolar plates and two copper sheets as current collectors. A square flow chamber (10 mm width × 10 mm lengh × 2.5 mm height) was carved in the center of the graphite plates as the discharging chamber. Hence, the prepared Ag2O@Ni foam electrode or a 2.5 mm-thick carbon felt can be embedded in the flow chamber. A proton exchange membrane sandwiched between these two electrodes was used to avoid the contact of anolyte and catholyte. Two fluid reservoirs in which electrolyte was stored were connected with graphite plates using silicone tubes. Driven by peristaltic pumps, the electrolyte flowed between the discharging chamber and the fluid reservoirs. Air or oxygen was continuously bubbled into the cathode reservoir to regenerate the cathodic electron carriers. For electricity generation, VO2 +/VO2+ was used as the cathodic electron carrier for four-electron reduction of oxygen. However, the kinetic rate of re-oxidation of VO2+ to VO2 + by air is very low, and thus HNO3 was used as a co-catalyst to promote the electron transfer in an internal recycle reactor developed by our lab [14]. For H2O2 production, oxygen was directly bubbled into the catholyte where AQS mediated two-electron reduction of oxygen to form H2O2. Moreover, heating rods were used to heat the graphite to analyze the influence of temperature. The cell performance such as polarization curve and amperometric I-t curve was measured using a CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. The power density curve was obtained according to the polarization curve based on the P = UI equation. Control experiments were conducted to investigate the effects of experiment conditions including the anode and cathode electrolyte composition, electron carrier concentration and temperature on cell discharging performance. For the anolyte, effect of furfural concentration (0–1 M) and KOH concentration (0–1 M) were investigated. For H2O2 production, effect of AQS concentration (0.005–0.5 M) and H2SO4 concentration (0–4 M) was investigated. Moreover, two proton exchange membrane namely Nafion 115 and Nafion 117 were used to compare the effect of membrane on cell discharging performance. 2.4 Analytic method 2.4.1 Determination of product concentration Quantification of furfural and furoic acid in the anode electrolyte were carried out by using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with an Aminex HPX-87H Column (300 × 7.8 mm) and detection via refractive index or UV absorption at 210 nm. 5 mmol/L H2SO4 was used as mobile phase, and the flow rate was 0.8 mL/min. The concentration of H2O2 formed by two-electron reduction of oxygen in cathode was determined by UV–vis method [15]. Under acid conditions, H2O2 can react with NH4VO3 to generate a stable orange complex which has a characteristic absorption peaks at 460 nm. Specifically, 100 μL catholyte was added into a 5 mL volumetric flask, followed by 400 μL 2 mol/L H2SO4 and 1 mL 2 g/L NH4WO3 solution. Then deionized water was added to the scale line. After standing for 5 min, the absorbance of the above solution at 460 nm was measured using an ultraviolet spectrophotometer. The concentration of H2O2 thus can be determined based on a prepared standard curve. 2.4.2 Electrochemical tests Electrochemical evaluation of the anode catalysts and the discharging performance of the LFFC were performed with a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co., Ltd, Shanghai, China). The cyclic voltammetry (CV) was carried out to analysis the cyclic reversibility of electron carriers with Ag/AgCl electrode as a reference electrode and Pt mesh as a counter electrode. For anodic electron carriers, the as-prepared metallic oxide@Ni foam electrode was used as working electrode while glassy carbon working electrode for cathodic electron carriers. The scanning speed was maintained at 5 mV/s. The polarization curve of the LFFC was achieved through the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) technique and swept from open-circuit voltage to zero voltages at 0.05 V s−1. 2.4.3 Characterization of the electrode catalysts A scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) (Hitachi S-3400 N II, Hitachi, Japan) was used to analyze morphology and composition the Ag2O@Ni anode. X-ray diffusion analysis (XRD) was conducted in a D/Max 2500H (Rigaku, Japan) diffractometer to analyze the change of crystallographic structure of the anode. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted in a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250 Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, MA, USA) to analyze the elemental chemical states of the anode catalyst. 2.4.4 Density function theory calculations All the calculations are performed in the framework of the density functional theory (DFT) with the projector augmented plane-wave method, as implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package [16]. The general gradient approximation (GGA)-Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) method is used to address the electronic exchange along with related effects [17]. The long range van der Waals interaction is described by the DFT-D3 approach [18]. The cut-off energy for plane wave is set to 500 eV. The energy convergence criterion is set to 10−5 eV in iterative solution of the Kohn-Sham equation. The Ag(111) surface is modeled by a three-layer 4 × 4 supercell. The spin polarization is considered in all structural optimization and energy calculations. A vacuum layer of 15 Å is added to the vertical direction to avoid artificial interaction between periodic images. The Brillouin zone integration is performed using 8 × 8 × 8 Gama-centered grids for the configuration optimization. All the structures are relaxed until the residual forces on the atoms have declined to less than 0.02 eV/Å. The climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method is employed to search the transition states of the related reactions [19]. The Gibbs free energy for furfural oxidation process is according to computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model, and computed by: ΔG = ΔE + ΔE ZPE − ΔTS + ΔG pH + ΔG U where ΔE is the computed reaction (electronic) energy, T is system temperature, and E ZPE and S are zero-point energy and entropy, respectively [20]. The effects of pH and electrode potential (U) can be treated as: ΔG pH = 0.0592 × pH and ΔG = −eU. In this work, the pH and electrode potential are set to 13. ΔG(ZPE-TS) are difference of zero-point energy and the entropy between the adsorbents on the slabs and adsorbents in the free states, respectively, which is obtained using the Vaspkit code [21], where the T is 300 K. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Working principle of the process Chemically, furfural can be easily oxidized by strong oxidants such as KMnO4, H2O2 [22] and molecular oxygen [23,24] to form furoic acid. Theoretically, such an oxidation reaction can be designed as a galvanic cell, where the oxidation reaction of furfural takes place on the anode, while reduction of oxidants takes place on the cathode, thus achieving conversion of chemical energy to electric energy (Fig. 1 a). The key issues to be solved to promote the efficiency of the process is to increase the rate of electron transfer and reduce the inner resistance of the cell. It can be expected that the kinetics of electrode reactions can be improved by using catalyst or electron carriers, by which electron transport chain (ETC) can be constructed [14]. Electron carriers with different electrode potentials can be employed to mediate the transport of electrons from furfural to the final electron acceptor O2. Currently, among the mediated fuel cell reported in the literatures, H2O was the final reduction product. However, by employing suitable catalysts to achieve two-electron reduction of oxygen, H2O2 can be produced in the cathode which further increases the potential revenue of the process. Therefore, such an LFFC system can achieve efficient production of value-added chemicals including furoic acid and H2O2 with simultaneous generation of electricity. When molecular oxygen is used as the oxidant, the overall reactions can be written as Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. Thermodynamic calculations showed that the change of standard Gibbs energy for these two reactions are −213.56 kJ/mol and −91.09 kJ/mol, respectively. Therefore, using LFFC to oxidize furfural by oxygen and produce H2O2 is thermodynamically feasible. The electrode potential of four-electron reduction of O2 to form water is 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is higher than that of two-electron reduction of O2 to form H2O2 (0.7 V, vs. RHE). Hence, the theoretical electromotive force of the LFFC system would decrease when H2O2 is co-produced leading to some decrease in the cell performance for electricity generation. (1) (2) The most crucial step to make this system work efficiently is to find suitable catalyst as electron carriers to construct an ETC. Compared with solid-state catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) like Pt/C, liquid catalyst can reduce the mass transfer resistance of gas diffusion, improving reaction kinetics. Our previous works on direct conversion of biomass to electricity have successfully screened a variety of cathode electron carriers that can mediate four-electrons reduction of O2, such as ferric salts [25–27], phosphomolybdic acid [28], and (VO2)2SO4 [29]. Among these electron carriers, (VO2)2SO4 with activation by HNO3 has the highest standard redox potential and can obtain the highest cell open circuit voltage (OCV). Therefore, it is preferred as a cathode electron carrier for four-electron reduction of oxygen in the cathode. For production of H2O2 in catholyte, currently a variety of anthraquinone derivatives like 2-ethylanthraquinone [30], sodium anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS) [31], anthraquinone-2-carboxylic acid [32] and 2,7-disulfonyl anthraquinone [33] have been found to well catalyze the electrochemical production of HP based on a proton coupled 2-electron transfer mechanism. With consideration of the solublity of the catalysts and the acidity of catholyte, AQS was selected for H2O2 production. Therefore, under the mediation of these electron carriers, the reactions taking place in the LFFC can be described as follow: In anode discharging chamber: (3) In this reaction, one molecule furfural releases two electrons to form furoic acid (two-electron pathway). This reaction is the typical and well-known mechanism for oxidation of furfural under alkaline condition. However, in our experiments, we also found that gas was formed on the surface of the anode during discharging process. It was identified that the gas was hydrogen. Recently, some works have reported that hydrogen indeed could be formed during chemical oxidation of furfural by heterogeneous catalysts such as ruthenium pincer catalysts [34], or electrochemical oxidation of furfural over Cu-based catalysts [35,36]. Therefore the following reaction also might take place: (4) This is a newly proposed mechanism by which one molecule furfural releases one electron and hydrogen atom to form hydrogen gas. It is termed one-electron pathway here. In cathode, the cathode electron carriers accept electrons from the electrode and then further transfer them to O2. When (VO2)2SO4 is used under the activation of HNO3 for four-electron reduction of oxygen, the cell can generate electricity with a high power density. The electrode reactions are described as follows: In the cathode discharging chamber: (5) VO 2 + + e - + 2 H + → VO 2 + + H 2 O In the cathode reactor for regeneration of vanadyl (V): (6) NO 3 - + 3 VO 2 + + H 2 O → 3 VO 2 + + NO + 2 H + (7) 2 NO + O 2 → 2 NO 2 (8) 3 NO 2 + H 2 O → 2 H + + NO + 2 NO 3 - When AQS is used as the cathode electron carrier for two-electron reduction of oxygen, the cell can generate electricity with co-production of H2O2. In the cathode discharging chamber: (9) In the cathode reactor: (10) Moreover, in this work we employed an acidic-alkaline asymmetric design in the LFFC system. Namely, KOH was used as an anolyte, while H2SO4 was chosen as the catholyte. This unique design was beneficial to increase the potential difference between cathode and anode by chemical bias, thus increasing the cell potential to drive the electron transfer without using exertional power source. 3.2 Oxidation of furfural to produce furoic acid with electricity generation 3.2.1 Modification of nickel foam anode to increase the oxidation of furfural and electron transfer Anode catalyst is a crucial factor for oxidation of furfural. An LFFC with nickel foam as the anode, carbon felt as the cathode and HNO3-activated (VO2)2SO4 as the cathode electron carrier, was firstly used for furfural oxidation and electricity generation. However, the reaction proceeded very slowly with power density less than 8 mW/cm2. It indicated that nickel foam anode could not well mediate the transfer of electrons from furfural. Therefore, modification of the Ni foam anode to promote anode reaction kinetics is crucial for achieving efficient oxidation of furfural and electricity generation. Metal oxides has been well employed to catalyze the oxidation of furfural by molecular oxygen. Therefore, we screened several metal oxides, including Fe2O3, CuO, NiO, CoO, MnO2 and Ag2O in order to modify Ni foam anode for improving the rate of electron transfer. As shown in the cyclic voltammograms of the modified Ni foam anode (Fig. S1 in Supporting Information), CuO, NiO, CoO, and Ag2O modification resulted in significant increase in the current when 50 mM furfural was present in the electrolyte; however, no apparent increase in the current was observed for Fe2O3 and MnO2 modified anodes. It indicates that CuO, NiO, CoO and Ag2O could be used as good anode catalysts to promote the kinetics of furfural oxidation. For example, as shown in the cyclic voltammograms of Ag2O modified anodes, two pairs of redox peaks could be observed in the absence of furfural which could be attributed to Ag/Ag2O and Ag2O/AgO redox couples respectively. After adding 0.1 M furfural to the electrolyte, a significant increase in the anodic current could be observed. It can be noted that the on-set potential on Ag2O modified anode is only −0.8 V vs. Ag/AgCl which was much lower than that of other metal oxide modified electrodes, indicating that Ag2O was the most efficient electrocatalyst for furfural oxidation. The cell performance was further tested with these modified anodes as shown in Fig. 2 . Significant increase in the power density was observed for the CuO, NiO, CoO and Ag2O modified anodes, while no apparent increase in the power output was observed for Fe2O3 and MnO2 modified anodes. These results were accordance with those observed by CV tests. Among the anodes, Ag2O anode could obtain much higher power density, indicating that it is the most suitable anode catalyst to catalyze the oxidation of furfural and mediate efficient transfer of electrons. Moreover, it was interesting to find that H2 could be produced when Ag2O was used as the catalyst in the LFFC system developed in this work, but no such phenomenon was observed when other catalysts were used. Recently, Wang et al. have developed an electrocatalytic system with Cu/Cu foam anode that achieves low-potential oxidation of furfural and release the hydrogen atom of the aldehyde group to for hydrogen gas [35,36]. However, in our system, we found that Cu/CuO anode could well catalyze the oxidation of furfural but could not work efficiently to release hydrogen gas. It indicated that anode catalyst is crucial for both oxidation of furfural and formation of H2. Therefore, in our system Ag2O was the most preferable anode catalyst to promote the transfer of electrons for furfural oxidation. Currently, silver-based compounds have been shown to be efficient and green catalysis to catalyze aldehydes to carboxylic acid reactions under mild conditions [37]. Liu et al. reported a homogeneous silver(I) complex capable of catalyzing aerobic oxidation of aldehydes in water conditions. A good versatility can be obtained for almost 50 kinds of aldehydes. However, the use of homogeneous catalyst was not conducive to subsequent separation procedure. More recently, Len et al. reported the selective oxidation of HMF to 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA) employing Ag2O as a heterogeneous catalyst. These results strongly suggest the potential application of Ag2O in quantitative catalytic oxidation of aldehydes [38]. As revealed in Fig. 2(b–d), the SEM images clearly showed that a conductive paincoats containing Ag2O particles were distributed on the Ni foam skeleton. The size of Ag2O particles was generally in the range of 0.5–1 μm. EDS analysis also indicated that the anode exhibited generally homogeneous distribution of silver, oxygen and carbon elements on the Ni foam skeleton. Therefore, by this modification, transfer of electrons from furfural to the electrode could be promoted. 3.2.2 Electricity generation with vanadyl(V) mediated four-electron reduction of oxygen When the LFFC is designed for oxidation of furfural with electricity generation, four-electron reduction of oxygen in cathode is expected in order to achieve a high output power density. In this case, promoting the kinetics of electron transfer to oxygen is important. In our previous work, we found that vanadyl(V) ((VO2)2SO4) was an efficient cathode oxidant and mediator to accept electrons. Moreover, ferric salts such as FeCl3, Fe2(SO4)3 and Fe(NO3)3 were also a promising candidate because of its low cost. The discharging performance of the cell with different cathode oxidants was compared as shown in supporting information Fig. S2. Using H2O2 for discharging without any cathode catalysts just obtained a relatively low peak power density (P max) (48 mW/cm2). O2 as the cathode oxidant with Pt/C as the catalyst significantly increased the P max to 101 mW/cm2, while Fe(NO3)3 and (VO2)2SO4 obtained much higher P max of 176 and 261 mW/cm2, respectively, under the conditions used. (VO2)2SO4 obtained higher P max because VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple had higher redox potential (Eθ = 1.0 V) than that of Fe3+/Fe2+ (Eθ = 0.76 V) to achieve stronger thermodynamic driving force for electron transfer. Moreover, VO2 + and Fe3+ could be easily regenerated with oxygen under the assistance of co-catalyst such as HNO3. These results indicated that liquid catalysts showed higher reaction rates for electron transfer because of much smaller mass transfer resistance on the electrode surface. It is expected that even higher power density and furoic yield could be obtained when electron carriers or oxidants with higher electrode potential than VO2 +/VO2+ such as Ce3+/Ce4+ and KMnO4/MnO2 are used. However, these electron carriers or oxidants are difficult to regenerate by air or oxygen at low temperature. Therefore, VO2 +/VO2+ redox couple seems to be the most preferable cathodic electron carriers in this LFFC system for furfural oxidation and electricity generation. The effects of several operating factors on the cell performance were further performed as shown in Fig. S2(b–e) with (VO2)2SO4 as the cathode mediator with 2 M H2SO4 as the supporting electrolyte. Increasing the alkalinity (KOH concentration) of anolyte significant increased P max (Fig. S2b), while Nafion 115 membrane showed superior property than Nafion 117 for the electricity generation by the LFFC system developed in this work (Fig. S2c). The concentration of furfural in anode relatively complicated effects on the P max of the cell (Fig. S2d). The power density was improved as furfural concentration increased from 0.01 M to 0.5 M, while further increasing furfural concentration oppositely decreased the power density. This was because higher furfural concentration could provide more electrons for electricity generation; however, the condensation reactions would become more significant to form humin that is detrimental to electrode reaction and electron transfer. 0.5 M seemed to be the optimal furfural concentration for electricity generation, which obtained 311 P max of 311 mW/cm2 with an OCV of 1.99 V. However, furoic acid yield decreased to 60% at 0.5 M initial furfural concentration, in contrast to 90% at 0.1 M furfural concentration. Increasing discharging temperature could significantly increase the power density of the cell. However, no apparent difference was obtained at 60 and 90 °C (Fig. S2e). This phenomenon can be explained by the formation of more humin from furfural at higher temperature. However, increasing discharging temperature significantly decreased fuoric acid yield, because furfural is chemically active in alkaline media to form various by-product. In the experiments, it was indeed found that fuoic acid yield decreased from 90 % at 25 ℃ to 37.6 % at 60 ℃. Therefore, it was recommended that the LFFC should be operated at room temperature with 0.1 M furfural concentration, which resulted in a P max of 261 mW/cm2, an OCV of 1.95 V, a short-circuit current density of 600 mA/cm2 and a furoic acid yield of 90 % in a batch operation. The LFFC developed in this work also can well convert various aldehydes including HMF, glucose, vanillin, benzaldehyde and p-hydroxy benzaldehyde, which are potentially derived from lignocellulosic biomass components, to electricity as shown in Fig. S2f. HMF that has similar structure with furfural achieved P max of 263 mW/cm2, followed by vanillin (229 mW/cm2). Glucose that can be easily obtained from hydrolysis of cellulose or starch resulted in moderate power density (136 mW/cm2); however, this value is at the highest level of reported direct glucose fuel cells. These results illustrated the versatility of Ag2O@Ni foam anode and effectiveness of the electron transport chain developed in this work to convert aldehydes to electricity. The efficiency of the LFFC system for production of furoic acid with electricity generation in a batch discharging process was shown in Fig. 3 . As the discharging proceeded, the output current density continuously decreased while the quantity of transferred electron increased (Fig. 3a). This was because the furfural was gradually oxidized in anode to form furoic acid. 95.7% of the initial furfural in anode was oxidized within the 50 min with 88.9% furoic acid yield. After discharging for 90 min, furfural was completely converted with 90% furoic acid yield. The gas released from anode reactor was collected, and hydrogen yield was determined as 0.097 mol/mol converted furfural, corresponding to 0.109 mol H2/mol formed furoic acid. This result indicated that the LFFC with the electron transport chain constructed in this work indeed could achieve efficient oxidation of furfural to produce furoic acid and hydrogen gas with good yield. However, the reactions of furfural in alkaline media are complicated. A part of the furfural may be oxidized in the liquid phase rather than on the electrode. For example, the Cannizzaro reaction of aldehydes under alkaline conditions as well as the oxidation of furfural by dissolved oxygen might take place, which results in the formation of furoic acid but no electrons are transferred to the anode. It was indeed found that after the anolyte was bubbled with N2, under a short-circuit discharging condition, furfural conversion was 100% but furoic acid yield decreased to 77.6%. We also performed control experiments under open-circuit condition, by which no electrons were transferred to external circuit. It was found that the conversion of furfural actually was as high as 82.4%, while the yield of furoic acid was only 39.3% (see supporting information Fig. S3). If the solution was treated with N2 bubbling, furfural conversion and furoic acid yield decreased to 70.7% and 27.3%, respectively. These results clearly indicated that under alkaline condition, Cannizzaro reaction and oxidation of furfural by dissolved oxygen indeed could take place, which obtained 39.4% furoic acid yield, while theoretically 61.6% furoic yield could be achieved by catalytic oxidation of furfural in the LFFC. Therefore, by assuming that the conversion of furfural to furoic acid on the anode proceeds by the two-electron pathway, it can be calculated that oxidation of one mol furfural on the anode could maximally release 1.23 mol electrons. Thus, the total Faraday efficiency of the LFFC was determined to be 92.5%, indicating that 92.5% of the theoretical quantity of electrons released through complete oxidation of furfural to furoic acid on the anode were captured to generate electricity. A relatively long-period operation with feeding of furfural at an interval time of 90 min was performed to obtain higher furoic acid concentration and continuous generation of electricity, as shown in Fig. 3(d–f). The output current density continuously decreased as the discharging proceeded in each batch operation, but current density sharply increased after feeding furfural, confirming the good activity and stability of the Ag2O@Ni foam anode. However, the maximal current density decreased as the feeding times increased primarily due to the accumulation of furoic acid and decrease in the alkalinity of the anolyte. As shown in Fig. 3e, furfural could be completely oxidized in each batch operation, and furoic acid concentration and H2 production generally linearly increased with fed-batch operation. The furoic acid yield was relatively stable at 90% with total Faraday efficiency at 94% for each fed-batch operation, corroborating the stability of the anode catalyst. After six batch operation, furoic acid concentration in the anolyte reached 0.53 mol/L (59.5 g/L). In a 50-mL anode reactor as used in the experiments, 29.5 mmol furfural was consumed, and 26.5 mmol furoic acid was produced with formation of 2.88 mmol H2. Moreover, during the discharging, 1985 Joule electric energy was harvested as electricity, corresponding to 8.53 kWh per standard cubic meter of the formed H2. Based on the chemical exergy of the products and electric work obtained by the LFFC, it was estimated that this system showed an exergy efficiency of 85.9%. 3.3 Oxidation of furfural with co-production of hydrogen peroxide 3.3.1 Confirmation of the effectiveness of AQS as a cathode catalyst for two-electron reduction of oxygen As described in the section of working principles of the developed system in this work, when the catalysts for oxygen reduction in cathode are selected as those for two-electron reduction of oxygen, H2O2 can be co-produced with the electrons released from oxidation of furfural. Thermodynamically, to make the system proceed spontaneously without input of external electric energy, we prefer to perform the reduction of oxygen in cathode in acidic media. It is preferred that the catalysts have good solubility in acidic media in order to obtain high reaction rates. It has been known that AQS catalyzes reduction of oxygen by two-electron electroreduction pathway to generate AQSH2, indicating that AQS was suitable for mediating H2O2 production. Therefore, in this work AQS was selected as a good candidate to achieve the utilization of the electrons released from furfural oxidation to reduce oxygen for H2O2 production. The electrochemical properties of AQS were tested by cyclic voltammetry as shown in supporting information Fig. S4. AQS displays a quasi-reversible CV curve in 1 mol/L H2SO4 media on carbon felt electrode. The half-wave potentials (E 1/2) of AQS was estimated as 0.159 V vs. NHE (−0.0384 V vs. Ag/AgCl), corresponding to a modest 0.55 V overpotential to the O2/H2O2 couple, suggesting that a sufficient thermodynamic driving force could be obtained for AQS mediated H2O2 production. As revealed by the plots of the peak current with the square root of scan rates (V 0.5), the electrode reaction kinetics of AQS-AQSH2 conversion was controlled by disunion since both the anodic peak current (i pa) and cathodic peak current (i pc) had very good linear relationship with V 0.5 (Fig. S4b). A constant voltage electrolysis experiment in a three electrodes system was further carried out in order to verify the efficiency of H2O2 production with AQS as the cathode catalyst. As shown in Fig. S4(c), when O2 was continuously supplied, the electrolysis current density was maintained at 110 mA/cm2 at voltage of −0.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl and kept stable. However, when N2 was continuously ventilated into the system, the detected current density decreased continuously. This was because the formed AQSH2 by reduction of AQS could not be reoxidized to AQS due to lack of oxygen. In comparison, the system without using AQS as the catalyst showed much lower current density (<10 mA/cm2) even O2 was continuously ventilated. These results definitely confirmed the effectiveness of AQS to mediate two-electron reduction of oxygen for H2O2 production. During the electrolysis at constant voltage of −0.2 V, H2O2 concentration in the system generally linearly increased as the reaction proceeded, and about 1.83 mmol H2O2 was produced within 60 min. The Faraday efficiency was stabled at about 88% (Fig. S4d). Therefore, AQS indeed is a good cathode catalyst to medicate two-electron reduction of O2 for H2O2 production with high. Therefore, electron transport chain can be constructed in an LFFC by using anode catalysts for promoting oxidation of furfural in anode in alkaline anolyte and AQS as a cathode catalyst for reduction of oxygen in cathode in acidic catholyte, by which furfural is converted to furoic acid with release of electrons that were further used to produce H2O2 without input of external electric energy. This LFFC converted the chemical energy of furfural oxidation to electric energy with co-production of chemicals. Several anodes including Ni foam, carbon felt, Ag2O@Ni foam, and Pd/C@Ni foam, were compared for electricity generation by this LFFC as shown in Fig. S4e. The highest peak power density and short circuit current density were obtained by using Ag2O/Ni foam electrode, being similar to the results found by using vanadyl(V) sulfate as the cathode electron carrier. The peak power density of LFFC using Ag2O@Ni foam anode was about four times higher than that of LFFC with Ni foam anode. Pd/carbon black, an efficient and commonly used electrocatalyst in direct alcohol fuel cells [39] was found to increase the power density to some extent compared with Ni form anode. However, its efficiency was still much poorer than that of Ag2O@Ni foam anode. These results further corroborated the high efficiency of Ag2O for promoting furfural oxidation in anode. 3.3.2 Cell performance for electricity generation with AQS as the cathode catalyst Similarly, the operation conditions were further investigated for electricity generation by the furfural fueled LFFC with AQS as the cathode catalyst and Ag2O@Ni foam as anode, keeping the discharging temperature at 25 °C to reduce the formation of humin in anode, as shown in supporting information Fig. S5. AQS concentration in catholyte did not significantly affect the performance of LFFC for electricity. The P max of the LFFCs with different AQS concentrations was between 33 and 35 mW/cm2. This result indicated that the rate of AQSH2 by O2 was high enough. Even at a low AQS concentration such as 5 mmol/L, could the electrons from furfural be rapidly transferred to O2. Since the electron transfer mechanism by AQS was accompanied by proton transfer, the effects of H2SO4 as the supporting electrolyte was further investigated. With the increase in H2SO4 concentration in the catholyte from 0.05 M to 4 M, P max apparently increased but no further increase was observed when H2SO4 concentration exceeded 1 M. Using acidic catholye is important for the LFFC developed in this work to achieve co-generation of electricity and production of H2O2. Generally, H2O2 is more stable in acid solution than in alkaline media, and therefore, H2SO4 can stabilize the formed H2O2. Moreover, according to Nernst equation, increasing H+ concentration would increase the electrode potential of AQS and thus enlarge the thermodynamic driving force for electrons transfer from furfural to oxygen. Moreover, higher conductivity can be obtained at a higher H2SO4 concentration which can reduce the internal resistance of the LFFC. P max increased with furfural concentration in anolyte. For example, P max increased from 16.5 mW/cm2 at 0.01 mmol/L furfural to 37.5 mW/cm2 at 0.1 mol/L furfural. But further increase in furfural concentration oppositely decreased the power density (Fig. S5c). This phenomenon was similar to that observed with vanadyl(V) as the cathode catalyst. Increasing KOH concentration in anode greatly improved the power density. P max could be enhanced to 46 mW/cm2 at 2 M KOH (Fig. S5d). Nafion 115 membrane showed better efficiency for electricity generation than Nafion 117, with P max being increased to 60 mW/cm2 (Fig. S5e). However, this power density was much lower than that obtained with vanadyl(V) as the cathode catalyst (216 mW/cm2), primarily due to the less redox potential of AQS. This LFFC also showed good versatility to convert various aforementioned aldehydes to electricity with P max in the range of 19 to 56 mW/cm2. HMF gave the highest power density of 56 mW/cm2, but glucose obtained the lowest (19 mW/cm2). As for three aldehyde compounds derived from lignin, vanillin showed the highest peak power density of 44 mW/cm2, followed by benzaldehyde (36 mW/cm2). Therefore, it is clearly confirmed that aldehydes indeed could be converted electricity with the Ag2O@Ni foam anode but the power density of the cell was also greatly dependent on the cathode electron carriers used. 3.3.3 Hydrogen peroxide production in cathode by AQS-mediated two-electron reduction of oxygen with furfural oxidation in anode A relatively long-period discharging of the LFFC was performed in short circuit condition in order to achieve quick transfer of electrons from furfural to produce furoic acid and H2O2. As shown in Fig. 4(a), as the discharging proceeded, the short-circuit current density decreased from 300 to 6 mA/cm2 after discharging for 90 min. 430 C of electric charges corresponding to 44.6 mmol electrons were transferred to the external circuit. The furfural concentration in the anolyte continually decreased to 0.0001 mol/L while furoic acid concentration increased steadily with 84.6% yield obtained after 90 min. H2O2 concentration in catholyte could reach 39.5 mmol/L (Fig. 4 b). Formation of H2 also clearly observed on the anode with yield of 0.141 mol/mol converted furfural, corresponding to 0.168 mol/mol formed furoic acid. In a batch operation after discharging for 90 min, this LFFC showed 74.5% anode Faraday efficiency and 87.6% cathode Faraday efficiency, resulting in 65.2% total efficiency (Fig. 4c), which indicated that 65.2% of the electrons released by oxidation of furfural on the anode were transferred oxygen to form H2O2. These results further corroborated that the developed LFFC system was versatile in co-production of furoic acid, H2 and H2O2 by promoting the electron transfer. Fed-batch operation was further performed with feeding furfural at every 90 min into the anolyte under short-circuit condition in order to minimize the external resistance for electron transfer, as shown in Fig. 4(d–f). As the discharging proceeded in each batch operation, the output current density continuously decreased, while current density sharply increased after feeding furfural. However, being similar to that observed for fed-batch operation of LFFC with vanadyl(V) as the cathode electron carrier, the maximal current density decreased as the feeding time increased. In each batch operation, furfural could be completely oxidized. Furoic acid concentration and H2 production in anode continuously increased. The furoic acid yield was in the range of 83–90% with anode Faraday efficiency of 76–81% for each fed-batch operation, and the cathode Faraday efficiency was relatively stable at 85–87%. After seven batch operation, furoic acid concentration in the anolyte reached 0.62 mol/L (69.4 g/L). In a 50-mL anode reactor as used in the experiments, 35 mmol furfural was consumed, and 31 mmol furoic acid was produced with formation of 5.21 mmol H2 in anode, while in the cathode, 14.5 mmol H2O2 was finally produced with H2O2 concentration of 0.29 mol/L. It was determined that a total of 3252 C electric charges corresponding 33.7 mmol electrons were transferred. Based on the chemical exergy of the formed products, it was estimated that this system had an exergy recovery efficiency of 82.6%. Reports on conversion of furfural to furoic acid by fuel cell system is very scarce, but some researches on oxidation of furfural in electrolytic cells are found, as summarized in Table 1 . In 2021, Wang et al. prepared Cu nanowires for oxidation of furfural on the anode with release of hydrogen gas, while oxygen reduction reaction occurred on the cathode over Pt/C catalyst, which transformed electrocataytic oxidation of furfural from electricity input to electricity out. By this system, ∼200 mW/cm2 of peak power density was achieved with furfural oxidation to furoic acid [35]. In the present work, we employed cheaper liquid redox couple (VO2 +/VO2+) as cathodic electron carriers, which significantly improved the kinetics of the oxygen reduction reaction on the cathode. Thus, higher power density was obtained. Reported electrolytic cell systems obtained a wide range of furoic acid yield of 30–100% depending on the catalyst used, cell design and operational conditions. However, the product concentration was usually below 20 g/L, typically lower than 10 g/L. Nevertheless, in the present work, much higher furoic acid concentration (∼60–70 g/L) was obtained with high yield (∼90%), indicating the good possibility for large-scale application of the developed system. Moreover, by using AQS as the cathodic electron carrier, H2O2 was co-produced, which definitely would increase the potential revenue of the process. 3.4 Mechanistic analysis of electron transfer in anode system In this work, the co-production of furoic acid, H2, H2O2 with generation of electricity was achieved by transfer of electrons from furfural to oxygen. Therefore, understanding the mechanism of electron transfer, especially in anode system is important. Using Ag2O particles as the anode catalysts indeed greatly improve the kinetics of furfural oxidation, indicating that the Ag2O plays an important role for electron transfer from furfural. We further investigated the structure change of the Ag2O particles in each step of discharging, as shown in Fig. 5 . The XPS and XRD spectra of freshly prepared Ag2O@Ni foam anode are shown in Fig. 5(a). The O 1s XPS spectra exhibits three major peaks at 529.7 eV and 531.5 eV representing Ag–O and OO bonds, respectively [38,45]. As for Ag 3d region, the Ag5/2 peak is found at 368.4 eV while the Ag3/2 peak appears at 374.4 eV, which is relatively close to the binding energy values of Ag+ in Ag2O [46]. As revealed by XRD spectra, diffraction peaks at 26.6°, 32.9°, 38.1°, 54.9°, 65.7°, 69.0°, and 81.5° were observed for Ag2O particles, which are assigned to the (110), (111), (200), (220), (311), (222) and (400) crystallographic planes of cubic Ag2O respectively [45]. After soaking the prepared anode in 2 M KOH solution containing 0.1 M furfural, only one peak at 532.9 eV was observed for deconvoluted O 1s XPS spectra. The peak corresponding to Ag–O bond at 529.7 eV disappeared. For the Ag 3d region, significant positive shift of 0.2 eV was observed after reaction, suggesting the formation of metallic Ag [47,48]. The XPS results were in good accordance to that of XRD results. After reaction, the XRD pattern of Ag2O anode displayed significant change. Several peaks at 38.1°, 64.4°, 77.4° and 81.5° assigned to (111), (220), (311) and (222) planes of metallic silver were detected. Hence, these results clearly indicated that Ag2O was reduced to the metallic Ag by furfural. To verify whether the formed Ag could be further oxidized to release electrons, the Ag2O anode soaked in alkaline furfural solution was rinsed with water and then equipped in the LFFC for discharging without fueling with furfural. For comparison, freshly prepared Ag2O anode was also tested under the same condition. As shown in supporting information Fig. S6. The fresh anode obtained very low power density of only 0.02 mW/cm2. However, the soaking treated anode that contained metallic Ag formed by oxidation of furfural obtained much higher power density (0.9 mW/cm2), indicating that the more electrons were transferred from the soaking treated anode. A relatively long-period discharging was performed for the soaking treated anode, in order to check whether the formed metallic Ag could be reoxidized to Ag2O. As shown in supporting information Fig. S7, after 5 h discharging under short-circuit condition, the current density decreased to 0.3 mA/cm2, while 25 C electric charges corresponding to 0.26 mmol electrons were transferred, suggesting that about 91% of the formed metallic Ag was reoxidized to Ag2O (33 mg of Ag2O were loaded on the anode) XPS and XRD analysis results (Fig. 5c) also confirmed the formation of Ag2O after the long-period discharging, because the peak signal in O 1s XPS spectra at 529.7 eV reappeared and the negative shift of Ag 3d signals was observed. More evidence can be found from the XRD pattern that the characteristic peak at 32.9° ascribed to (111) crystallographic planes of cubic Ag2O reappeared, while the signal of characteristic peak at 64.4° ascribed to (220) crystallographic planes of cubic Ag became much weaker [49]. It thus corroborated that the electron transfer during oxidation of furfural in anode was indeed achieved by the change of the valence state between Ag2O and Ag. Based on the above results, we thus have proposed the plausible reaction mechanisms on the Ag2O-catalyzed oxidation of furfural on the anode of the LFFC system developed in this work, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). According to the number of electrons transferred from one molecule of furfural to the anode, we proposed two possible pathways for the oxidation of furfural to furoic acid on the Ag2O anode surface. One-electron pathway represents that only one electron is transferred, while two-electron pathway means that two electrons are transferred during oxidation of one molecule of furfural. Since the anode reaction takes place in alkaline media, it is the most possible that the reaction is initiated by the nucleophilic attack of a hydroxide ion on the carbonyl carbon of the aldehyde group thus giving a hydrate anion (gem-diolate anion, GDA). The next step is the transfer of the hydride ion, or known as dehydrogenation process, which results in release of two electrons from the hydrate anion. In Cannizzaro reaction, the hydride ion is transferred onto the carbonyl carbon of another aldehyde molecule, resulting in formation of a carboxylate and alkoxide ion which subsequently forms furfuryl alcohol. This reaction indeed could take place as aforementioned discussion that furoic acid was formed under the open-circuit condition, even that the dissolved oxygen was purged with high-purity nitrogen. In this work, due to the presence of Ag2O catalysts on the anode, the hydride ion may be transferred onto Ag+, leading to reduction of Ag+ to form metallic Ag and formation of adsorbed H-species (hydrogen atoms) on the surface. There are two possible pathways for the fate of the adsorbed hydrogen atoms. In the one-electron pathway, the hydrogen atom gets desorbed, and two adjacent hydrogen atoms combine to form hydrogen gas. In the two-electron pathway, due to the oxidation of metallic Ag to form Ag+, one more electron is further transferred to reduce Ag+ to Ag with formation of H+ that is captured by a hydroxide ion to form water. As found in the experiments, the molar yield of H2 was 9.8% and 14.9% with vanadyl(V) and AQS as the cathode electron carriers, respectively, indicating that two-electron pathway is more prone to take place for furfural oxidation on Ag2O@Ni foam anode. Density function theory (DFT) calculations are further performed, and the free energy diagram for the oxidation of furfural are shown in Fig. 6(b). Corresponding structures of the reactants, intermediates and stable adsorption configurations are shown in Supporting Information Figs. S8–S13. The results illustrate that both the one-electron and two-electron pathways are thermodynamically possible. However, the products of the two-electron pathway (FCA + H2O) have lower free energy (−5.61 eV) compared to those of one electron pathway (FCA + H2) (−2.94 eV), indicating that the two-electron pathway is more thermodynamically feasible. Nevertheless, because of the lower energy barrier (ΔE a = 0.87 eV for one-electron pathway compared to 1.02 eV for two-electron pathway), hydrogen atoms resulting from CH splitting can also be combined to form H2 under the driving force of the potential difference between cathode and anode. The DFT calculation results are in good agreement with the experimental results. It is proposed that proper adsorption force of hydrogen atom on the catalyst is important for the priority of formation of H2 or H2O (one-electron pathway or two-electron pathway). If the catalyst has too strong ability to grasp electron from the adsorbed hydrogen atom, no hydrogen gas would be formed. As found in this work, Ag2O was the one probably with moderate adsorption force of hydrogen atom, so that release of gaseous hydrogen was observed. However, the cathode electron carriers or oxidants in catholyte may also show significant effects on the kinetics of electron transfer, and thus affecting the H2 yield. More details are worth of studying in future works. 4 Conclusions In this work we have developed a new LFFC system with metal oxide especially Ag2O as anode catalysts and liquid redox couples as electron carriers for reduction of oxygen in cathode. By promoting and controlling the kinetics of electron transfer, oxidation of furfural to furoic acid with production of hydrogen gas and H2O2 as well as generation of electricity were achieved. The system efficiency was further improved by using an asymmetric alkaline-acidic electrolyte design for increasing the driving force of electron transfer. By using vanadyl(V) sulfate under the activation of HNO3 as the cathode electron carrier for four-electron reduction of oxygen, a maximal power density (P max) of 261 mW/cm2 with furoic acid and H2 yields of 0.9 and 0.10 mol/mol furfural were obtained at room temperature. By using AQS as the cathode electron carrier for two-electron reduction of oxygen, a P max of 60 mW/cm2 with furoic acid, H2 and H2O2 yields of 0.88, 0.15 and 0.41 mol/mol furfural, respectively, were achieved at room temperature. A plausible mechanism referring one-electron and two-electron pathway oxidation of furfural at Ag2O@Ni anode has been proposed depending on the fate of adsorbed hydrogen atom that is transferred from the splitting of CH in the aldehyde group, which may result in formation of H2 or H2O, respectively. This work thus may provide new insights into the conversion of chemical energy of biomass-derived aldehydes to electricity and co-production of multiple products by making full use of the transferred electrons, and enlighten new understanding of the mechanism of furfural oxidation over metal catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Conventional chemical oxidation of aldehydes such as furfural to corresponding acids by molecular oxygen usually needs high pressure to increase the solubility of oxygen in aqueous phase, while electrochemical oxidation needs input of external electric energy. Herein, we developed a liquid flow fuel cell (LFFC) system to achieve oxidation of furfural in anode for furoic acid production with co-production of hydrogen gas. By controlling the electron transfer in cathode for reduction of oxygen, efficient generation of electricity or production of H2O2 were achieved. Metal oxides especially Ag2O have been screened as the efficient catalyst to promote the oxidation of aldehydes, while liquid redox couples were used for promoting the kinetics of oxygen reduction. A novel alkaline-acidic asymmetric design was also used for anolyte and catholyte, respectively, to promote the efficiency of electron transfer. Such an LFFC system achieves efficient conversion of chemical energy of aldehyde oxidation to electric energy and makes full use the transferred electrons for high-value added products without input of external energy. With (VO2)2SO4 as the electron carrier in catholyte for four-electron reduction of oxygen, the peak output power density (P max) at room temperature reached 261 mW/cm2 with furoic acid and H2 yields of 90% and 0.10 mol/mol furfural, respectively. With anthraquinone-2-sulfonate (AQS) as the cathodic electron carrier, P max of 60 mW/cm2 and furoic acid, H2 and H2O2 yields of 0.88, 0.15 and 0.41 mol/mol furfural were achieved, respectively. A new reaction mechanism on furfural oxidation on Ag2O anode was proposed, referring to one-electron and two-electron reaction pathways depending on the fate of adsorbed hydrogen atom transferred from furfural aldehyde group.

coredata.dc:title: Promoting and controlling electron transfer of furfural oxidation efficiently harvest electricity, furoic acid, hydrogen gas and hydrogen peroxide
